I am a carpenter, of 4, Middlesex-terrace, Hackney—I was at Hackney-marshes on the morning of Easter Monday; it was the part near Bow—I was never there before; it was an open field—there were a hundred persons present—about half-past 6 in the morning, I saw the prisoner Howlett there, and the deceased Rivett; they were both stripped—there was no ring made, only by the people—the prisoner Howlett and the deceased were in an open space—they then began to fight—they fell several times—I waited until it was over; they fought about an hour—when they fell they were sometimes assisted up—I could not tell who assisted; they were strangers—I cannot say whether or not the same persons picked them up on each occasion—I saw the deceased at the end of the fight on the field, lying on the ground—I did not see him struck down—I did not see him removed—I next saw him at the "Morpeth Castle" public-house, lying on the table—that is, I think, three or four hundred yards from the field—there were some men standing round him, but I did not stop to see what they were doing; they were rubbing him—he appeared to be insensible—I did not hear any one speak to him—I was present at the "Mary Ann Arms" public-house before the fight—I saw Howlett there, and he put some money down; it was 3l. 10s., I believe—I lent him some money, but for what purpose I do not know—he asked me to lend him some money, as he had done before—he said, "Wood, lend me a couple of pounds," and I heard no more of it until I heard from him afterwards what it was for—I asked him what he put the money down for, and he said he was going to fight a party—I knew who it was; he said Rivett—there was nothing more said—he did not tell me when, or say anything about the fight—when the money was put down, Howlett, myself, the two Hammonds, were present—their father keeps the house—I did not notice any one else—they were on the serving side of the bar—I did not know what became of the money; I did not see any one pick it up.

Cross-examined by MR. DALEY. Q. How long have you known Howlett? A. Twelve years—he has always been a quiet and peaceable man—I knew deceased about four years—I heard Rivett challenge Howlett—he challenged the whole four several times—he did not challenge me especially, he chal
lenged all, whoever liked to take it up—he was an excitable, nervous man when he had been having drink—I have known him to be unable to resume work in consequence of trembling and nervousness after drinking—I have seen him become insensible, from some kind of fit, two or three times—having been drunk, he would be excited, and sing, and then go off into a

fainting state—that occurred three or four times slightly, but once very bad—at the fight there was a good deal of swaying and moving about—when the men fell the people were pressing on them, and then moving back to make room again—I did not see who lifted the men up—Rivett had a good deal the best of the fight all the first part—he dropped several times without being hit; it was what they call "flinching" from Howlett—I heard some of the crowd calling out to Rivett as to how he was to strike Howlett—he was nearly blind, and they said, "Hit him on the other eye"—one was quite blind, and the other was much swollen, so that he must have won if the other had been hit—he tried after that to hit pretty hard—Howlett bled wonderfully—I cannot say how long Rivett was left on the ground after filling—he was left on the grass half an hour before he was removed—I did not see any covering put on him—it was early in the morning—the grass was damp.

COURT. Q. What became of you during the half-hour? A. I went away—from the time I saw him on the grass until I saw him again was half an hour—I think he was left half an hour before he was brought in—I saw him knocked down insensible—I never interfered—there were plenty of people round—I was about the first that left the place.

MR. PALMER. Q. Did not any one object to his being unfit to fight be
cause he was excitable? A. No; we all hindered him from fighting a great many times, but we let him fight in this case—though knowing he was going to fight, I did not stop him or tell him that he was unfit to fight—I re
mained an hour, until it was all over, though I could not always see.

COURT. Q. You knew of the fight, and went down to see it, I suppose? A. Yes; I did not go down with a great many others—I knew of it about a week before—I did not see marks upon the deceased; none at all—I saw blows struck upon him; they were in different places—I could not tell exactly where he was hit; it was about the breast at times—he did not seem hurt at all—I did not see any unfair blow struck by Howlett—I am quite certain of that.

WILLIAM ROBERT PIERPOINT . I live at 18, Well-street, Hackney—on Easter Monday, at half-past 6 in the morning, I was in Hackney-marshes—I saw the fight between the deceased Rivett and Howlett—there were about a hundred persons present, and a ring was formed by the people, but no rope ring—I believe there were "seconds," but who they were I do not know—I saw some person with a sponge in his hand, but I did not see it used, nor did I see anybody with a watch in hand—I remained about ten minutes or a quarter of an hour—I saw the beginning of the fight—both parties hit one another, and knocked one another down several times.

Cross-examined by MR. DALEY. Q. Did Rivett ever challenge you? A. Yes; that was three or four weeks previously to this fight—he has chal
lenged the whole firm—I have known Howlett for twelve years; he was generally quiet and peaceable—I heard a great deal of hallooing during the fight—I heard same one say to Rivett in the commencement, if he saw a blow coming, and could not get away in time, to fall—I saw him fell afterwards, and he fell at the first commencement of the fight—I mean falling with a blow, and falling to avoid one—I do not know the rules of fighting—I should not think it was a fair way of fighting.
COURT. Q. Did you see the other three prisoners there? A. Yes.
JOHN PRIOR . I reside at 5 Goldsmith's-row, Hacknty, and was present at the fight—I saw the prisoner Lewis there—some one brought him a
sponge, and he sponged Howlett over the eyes, which were bleeding—I only. saw Rivett, Howlett, and Lewis.

Cross-examined by MR. DALEY. Q. Was Howlett a good deal punished? A. He was bleeding profusely—the deceased had the best of the fight until nearly the last—I saw him sometimes drop without being struck—I did not hear any one call out to him—the deceased had appeared to be the best man up to the last two rounds.

Cross-examined by MR. BEST. Q. How near were you to Howlett while the fight was going on? A. Sometimes I was close on the ring—the sponge handed to Lewis came from some one in the crowd—I won't say what part of the fight that was; I think it was at the commencement.

MR. PALMER. Q. In what condition was the deceased during the last two rounds? A. He came up with his head hanging on one side, and that caused great confusion—I got out, and saw no more of the fight—the crowd all got together—I suppose they fancied it was getting towards the end.

COURT. Q. You did not see the end? A. No; I speak of up to the last two rounds; I did not see them—I do not know what round it was that Rivett came up with his head hanging on one side—I heard there were two more rounds—when I went away Rivett was coming up with his head hang
ing on one side—his "seconds" brought him up; he had two "seconds"—he was lifted up from the ground—I went away because I had seen enough of the fight—I went to the public-house where the man was brought back—I was there perhaps half an hour to that—I do not know who brought him—he was carried along by three or four men to the "Morpeth Castle"—that is not quite half a mile from where the fight was—the deceased was insensible—they laid him on a table, and rubbed him with vinegar on the chest—he remained about half an hour after he was brought in.

MR. DALEY. Q. What hour was it when you left the ground? A. I should think it must have been about 8—it was about half an hour before I saw Kivett at the public-house—I saw no unfair blow struck—I had not known of the fight before that morning—I generally take a walk in the morning, and I saw this crowd on the marshes at a little after 7.

EDMOND VALENTINE . I live at Exeter Cottage, Old Ford-road, and am a bricklayer—I was present at the commencement of the fight—I saw Howlett and Lewis there—I saw Lewis rubbing Howlett's face once, and heard him say, "Drive in with your right"—I do not know whether he addressed How
lett or the other one—I cannot exactly say the position he was in; he was among the crowd—he was as far from one as the other; they were all over the field in the course of fighting—I could not say what round it was; I was not in the ring all the time—I saw a man holding a watch, keeping time, but who it was I do not know—he cried out, "Time!" at the com
mencement of every round.

COURT. Q. When did you first know of it? A. On the Wednesday morning before it took place I went out with my gun—I heard there was a fight coming off, but whether it was this fight I do not know—the person who told me works at the pitch factory over the bridge—I saw the crowd assembled, and walked over to see it—I waited until it ended by one of the combatants being carried off the ground—I cannot say whether before he was carried off he fell—I was not in the crowd until the last round—having a gun with a hair-trigger, I thought there might be an accident, and I stood on some rails—in the last round I saw a commotion; I said, "I think it is all over"—I ran up to the crowd, and I saw some one throw a cap up, and the deceased lying on the ground, with a horsecloth over the lower port of

his person—a man whose name I heard mentioned as Grant was acting as his "second," said, "Who will carry him off will some of you carry him?"—two or three objected, and a person came up and said, "I have a trap, put him in that;" but at last two persons carried him off the field in, I should say, five or six minutes afterwards—they took two or three minutes trying to put on his shirt, and when they could not do so they threw a horsecloth' over his shoulders; they were both stripped to the waist—I met a friend, and did not follow the crowd—I went to the Morpeth Castle, and saw him on the table, and two men rubbing him with vinegar—he was insensible.

HENRY ROBINSON . I am a groom, residing at 5, Bell-row, Old Ford—I was at the fight between Rivett and Howlett—a ring was formed by the people—I only recognise Lewis as being there—I saw him wet a sponge from the water in the reservoir—he returned and handed it to the man that had Howlett on his knee—I stayed to the end of the fight—Rivett seemed then insensible; his eyes rolled about, and he had no use in them—he was knocked down by Howlett on his back, and was lying on the ground—I do not know where the blow hit him—he seemed all of a shiver, and foamed at the mouth—he was then wrapped in a horse-rug and carried off—before he was knocked down he was held up by his seconds—he did not seem to know what he was doing.

Cross-examined by MR. DALEY. Q. When he was held up by his seconds, did they go away from him? A. They stood back—he did not fall of him
self; he was knocked down—he was not pushed—I cannot say in what posi
tion his arms were—I was not inside the ring—I do not know whether it was a hard blow or not, or whether it was on the head or chest—Rivett might have had his arms up in a position of defence.

COURT. Q. Did you see Rivett brought up the last round but one? A. Yes—he seemed insensible then—his seconds brought him up—he was knocked down by Howlett—he seemed to be able to defend himself a little the last round but one—his eyes were not rolling or his mouth foaming the last round but one—the last round it was so—he seemed all of a cold shiver the last round—it was a very short time after he was held up that he was knocked down—I do not suppose it was more than half a minute.

JOHN ODDY . I reside at Weston-street, Stratford, and am a signal-man on the Great Eastern Railway—I was present at part of the fight between Rivett and Howlett some time after 7—I do not know how long they had been fighting—I saw ail four of the prisoners there—Lewis had got a sponge or rag washing Howlett's face when I saw him—William Hammond had a watch in his hand, and was calling "time" while the fight was proceeding—when they had fallen he called "time" for them to come up again—he had two. men as seconds—I do not know who they were—they bathed his head a great deal with cold water out of a basin; I do not know by whom—I did not remain to the end—I was there some time; then I went away for a few minutes, and went back again—while I was to and fro they fought about a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes I should think—I was there before the last round began—when his seconds set him up he was first let go, and knocked down again directly—he made no defence with his hands the last round—he did not seem capable of anything—I saw him fall—he lay there about five or six minutes; I cannot tell exactly—there was a loud talking and noise—I did not hear anything said in particular—if I am to speak the truth, I should say it was not a fair fight in the last round, because the man could not stand up to fight.
Cross-examined by MR. DALEY. Q. Did his seconds loose hold of him? A.

As soon as they got him up, they were just going to let go, and he was hit again—he was hardly let go when he was hit—he was hardly standing—I believe he would have dropped if he had not been knocked down—the de
ceased seemed to be the best man all through the early part of the fight—Howlett was a good deal punished—he hit the deceased in the neck, I believe, the last time—he did not hit him very hard, not so hard as the last round before.

Cross-examined by MR. BEST. Q. Who got you to give evidence about this fight? A. That is my business—the policeman came down—I give my evidence according to my own opinion—I do not know why I did not tell you at first that the policeman came down—I have never seen him but twice in my life, and then it was in the signal-box—I do not know that he told me what I was to do—he asked me about the fight, and told me I must give evidence before the Coroner—I am signal-man now—I cannot say I deserted my post that morning—people came on the line, and it is my duty, when I see people on the line trespassing, to order them off, and they were fighting in a field below—I was suspended by the Railway Company, but the Directors thought it was part of my duty to order the people off the line, and the place from which I saw the fight was not above a hundred yards from my post—I went away a hundred yards and into the field—I cannot say how long I was there—I did not look at the time; it might have been a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes—I was not mixed up with all the rabble that was there—I did not want to see—I did not know anything about any of them—it was before I was on duty—the first train had not run—it was half an hour before—the train is not down there until half-past 7—I ordered them off the line, and then I went on to see the fight.

MR. PALMER. Q. Is that but a short distance from your box? A. About a hundred yards—I was suspended for a time in consequence of leaving for that short distance, but after my explanation of the case to them, the Directors restored me at the recommendation of the Magistrate, and I was told by the Board of Directors to go back to my duty again.

COURT. Q. Were you told that, in consequence of the evidence you had given in reference to this, you would be restored? A. I told the Chairman that, in consequence of there being a fight, the people were standing on the line, and I ordered them off and stopped to see the fight a few minutes—I was ordered out of the room and called in again, and the Chairman said, "Well, Oddy, you are an old servant, you have been sixteen years signal
man and bear a good character; go back to your duty, and we will allow the penalty of your being suspended," and I went back to my duty again.
HENRY BARNETT (Policeman, 299 K). I took Howlett on 7th April—I told him I came to take him on a charge of fighting—he said, "Yes, I am quite willing to go"—I told him where he fought.

GEORGE ATKINS (Policeman, 463 K). I took the Hammonds into custody on 15th April—I told them I charged them with aiding and assisting How
lett in causing the death of Samuel Rivett—they said they were at the fight on the morning in question, but denied aiding and assisting him—I also told them that they were further charged with receiving a certain amount of money as stakes—the elder Hammond said he did not receive any money, and the other made no reply—I took Lewis on 17th April—I told him he was charged with aiding and assisting Howlett in causing the death of Rivett—he said he was at the fight on the morning, but did not aid or assist.
JAMES APPLEYARD . I am house-surgeon to the London Hospital—the de

ceased was brought in on the morning of 6th April, a few minutes before 10—I examined his body—he was dead when I saw him—I made a post-mortem examination—I found marks of contusions over the head, face, chest, shoulders, and hands; the scalp was extravasated with blood—on removing the skull-cap, I found a large coagulum of congested blood on both hemi
spheres of the brain, which was congested—the lungs and air passages were congested also—all the other organs were perfectly healthy—I attribute death to the effusion of blood on the brain, which could be caused by a blow at a prize fight—hearing what happened before, I do not entertain any doubt that effusion had been caused by the violence that had been inflicted.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. May effusion of blood on the brain be caused by other means than violence? A. Yes; from disease, of from a sudden rupture of one of the vessels in the brain—a rupture of one of the vessels in the brain sometimes takes place without there having been exter
nal violence, as in the case of apoplexy—excitement brought on, whether from physical or mental causes, will result in apoplexy or the rupture of the vessels of the brain; it depends upon the age in a great measure—it is very extraordinary to see it under a certain age—in my own experience, I have not found it any so young.

Q. I am asking you, as a gentleman of science and reading on this matter, no age is exempt from it under certain circumstances? A. I cannot fully answer that question; not from disease; from injury—I never heard of it occurring in anyone so young—mental excitement might produce a rupture of a blood vessel in the brain at any age—when there is a rupture quite in
dependent of any blow or any fall, there is generally ossification of the tissues—I cannot say that the excitement of fighting a person who has undergone training would produce a rupture by the sudden change from severity of living to the excitement of fighting, without violence—I could not say, unless the tissues of the blood vessels had been diseased—it might, but I cannot say—I have never known a case occur except in cases where the tissues of the vessels have been diseased by bony deposits—from my examination I observed general extravasation over the two hemispheres of the brain—I should not expect to find extravasation only at the particular spot where a person has received injury from a blow or a kick—it depends upon where the blow was struck—if he received a blow over the temple, and the skull was fractured, and an artery ruptured, I should expect to find extravasation from the concussion to the head throughout—if there was a large blood vessel ruptured, it would flow all over the interior surface; it would depend also upon what position the body laid in; the blood would gravitate—I could not swear what particular vessel in the brain was ruptured—some might be produced by the post mortem in the act of getting off the skull-cap—the longitudinal sinus was ruptured in two places—I could not say whether that was produced before death or after—great force is required in removing the skull-cap—this clot could not have been caused by the removal of the skull-cap—no doubt, when the skull-cap is torn off, it must rupture some of the vessels—you are obliged to take the calvarium off with great force—the rupture of a blood vessel would be doubtful, but I have no doubt about the clot—it was not a clot in one single place, but over both hemispheres.
MR. PALMER. Q. To the best of your judgment, considering all that has been said, was the rupture caused by mental excitement or violence? A. By violence.

SAMUEL RIVETT . I reside at 8, Prospect-place, and am the father of the ceased—he was twenty-three years of age in the March preceding his death—I last saw him alive on 6th April, at quarter to 5 in the morning in

my own house—he was then in good health—there was nothing the matter with him that I am aware of—he was as healthy a young man as could he found—I never knew of his having fits or falling from excitement—he scarcely ever had a headache in his life—I cannot say he was sober in his habits, but he was not a drunkard—he came home tipsy sometimes, princi
pally on a Saturday when he had been taking his money—he was paid at a public-house—I never knew of his having any serious illness.

p.hi: Lewis and the two Hammonds received good characters.

div1.p:
GUILTY .—Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury, considering that the deceased provoked the fight.—
Confined two months each, and to
enter into recog
nisances to keep the peace.

739.
JOHN STEPHENSON (24), and
THOMAS JOKES (16),
PLEADED GUILTY
to stealing 1 cwt. 58 lbs. of metal pipe, the property of
William George Winchman .—STEPHENSON
Confined Twelve Months. —THOMAS JONES—
Six Months.

740.
ANN PRIOR (23), was indicted
for unlawfully endeavouring to conceal the birth of her child.—MR. WAY conducted the Prosecution; and MR. ORRIDGE the Defence.
NOT GUILTY .

741.
CHARLES JONES (28)
, Stealing a pair of pistols, value 12l., the property of
William George Groves, in his dwelling-house.

WILLIAM GEORGE GROVES . I am a surgeon at Woodford—on Saturday, 5th April, I was possessed of a pair of pistols in a case and two photographic lenses—on that day the brace of pistols were in the case on a box in a back room on the ground-floor, and the lenses were on the table—I saw them safe late on Saturday night, and on the Monday morning they were gone—they must have been stolen—the door of the room was shut, but not locked—it com
municated directly with the backyard—I attended on the following Friday at the police-court—the prisoner was there, and one of my pistols was pro
duced by the constable—this is it—I identified it at the police-court.

WILLIAM MARTIN . I am a butcher of Woodford—on Wednesday, 6th April, at half-past 12, I saw the prisoner in Woodford New-road, going to
wards the prosecutor's house—about a quarter-past 1, I saw him again about 100 yards from the house, coming away—he had something under his coat, which appeared like a dressing-case, brass bound at the corners—he passed me—I walked on some distance, thinking something was wrong—he then ran round the corner into the forest—that was the last I saw of him.

JOHN CLARK (Policeman, K 491). On 6th April, about 3 o'clock in the afternoon, I saw the prisoner at Mr. Byas's, a pawnbroker's in George-street, Ratcliffe-highway, offering this pistol in pledge, for 6s.—I was at the door, and could hear what be said—I was in uniform—he saw me—I asked him about it and he said he got it off his brother for 8s.—I asked him where he lived—he said he lived in Union-street, Whitechapel, but he could not tell the number—I took him into custody, and took possession of the pistol—produced it at the police-court, and I produce it now—I made a charge against the prisoner of unlawful possession.

COURT. to WILLIAM GEORGE GROVES. Q. Was the case brass bound at the corners? A. Yes; and also at the sides—it would look like a dressing-case—being a medical man, my yard gate is always left open, and any one could come in—I very seldom go into into this room on Sunday, and that is why I did not miss the things till the Monday.
Prisoner's Defence. I received the pistol, but I did not steal it.

GUILTY .—
Confined Nine Months.

742.
THOMAS FISHER (23)
, Stealing a watch, the property of
Oba
diah Corbett, from his person.

OBADIAH CORBET . I live, at 1, Halsville-Cottages, West Ham, and am an iron boat-builder—about half-past 9 o'clock on the night of 4th May, I was in Halsville-road, Plaistow-marsh, looking at a man selling jewellery—there were some people there, and I felt the prisoner's hand in my pocket, taking my watch out—I had seen my watch not many minutes before—I tried to catch hold of the prisoner, but he ran against me and I could not—I saw him with the watch, and another witness saw him pass it—I valued it at 30s.—I have never seen it since—I never lost the prisoner till the officer came up—my watch-guard was not broken; the rivet through the ring of the watch was broken.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see a lad about fourteen at your right arm? A. No—I did not see anything in your hand; you dropped something, but I don't know what.

THOMAS LYONS . I am a labourer, of 10, Victoria-dock-terrace, West Ham—on the night of 4th May, about half-past 9, I was by the prosecutor in a crowd—I saw the prisoner on his right side—I noticed him moving in different parts of the crowd, and heard the prosecutor say, "I have lost my watch"—directly he said that the prisoner got in front of him, put his hand over my shoulder with something white and round in it, and passed it to somebody else, who made his way out of the crowd—the prosecutor had hold of the prisoner then, and I caught hold of his other arm and pulled it down, but the watch was gone—the prisoner said, "I have not got your watch, but I know who has."
Prisoner. Q. Had I not some songs in my hand? A. No—it was not a bundle of songs that you passed over.

GEORGE PAGE (Policeman, K 55). On 4th May the prisoner was given into my custody by the prosecutor, who charged him with stealing his watch—the prisoner said he did not know anything about it—I searched him immediately, and found some songs and twopence in copper on him; nothing else.

Prisoner's Defence. I was standing in this crowd for curiosity, and saw a lad by the side of the prosecutor, and happened to go past him, and he said, "You have got my watch;" I looked, and the lad was gone; I said, "I have not; you can search me;" there was a great crowd, and they knocked me about; I am innocent.

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

743.
ELIZABETH WRIGHT (24)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.
ANNIE STEWARD . I am assistant to Mr. Beasley, a draper, at Stratford—on Thursday, 7th May, about half-past 5 in the evening, the prisoner came
to the shop, and I served her with some ribbon, which was 6 3/4d.—she gave me a bad half-crown; I gave her change, and she left the shop—I gave that half-crown to Miss Nicholl, the cashier.

ELIZA NICHOLL . The last witness gave me a half-crown, from which I took 6 3/4d., and gave her the change—I put the half-crown in a pigeon-hole at the back of my desk—Mr. Beasley came in soon alter and took it up—it was a bad one.
HENRY BEASLEY . I found this half-crown was bad, and afterwards gave it to the constable Brooks.

SEPTIMUS MORRIS . I am a stationer, at Stratford, about three doors from Mr. Beasley—on Thursday, 7th May, the prisoner came to my shop, about 6 or 7 o'clock, and asked for some steel pens—she gave me a half-crown, and I gave her change—I kept the half-crown in my hand; I had some sus
picion about it—Brooks came in while I was examining it, and I gave it to him at the station—he went after the prisoner.

WILLIAM BROOKS (Policeman, K 44). I went to Mr. Morris's shop and received some information about the prisoner—I had seen her in the shop before I went in—I went after her and took her into custody in Skinner's-court, about 80 or 100 yards from Mr. Morris's—she had a purse in one hand and something in the other—I took hold of both her hands and said she must come to the station—with the assistance of the inspector and a constable I opened her hand, and found these two counterfeit half-crowns (produced)—I also received a half-crown from Mr. Morris, and another from Mr. Beasley (produced)—the purse contained 6s. in good money, and the female searcher handed me 2s. 3d., and 4 1/2 d. in coppers, good money, and said in the presence of the prisoner, "That is all I have found on her."
WILLIAM WEBSTER , These four half-crowns are counterfeit, and the two that were passed are from the same mould.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not know that they were bad; a man gave me one half-crown for some stamps I had.

GUILTY .*—
Confined Fifteen Months.

744.
JOSEPH HOLLAND (47)
, Stealing money to the amount of 36l., the property of
Thomas Barker, and other articles, in the dwelling-house of
Richard Beckham.

THOMAS BARKER I live at 3, Reginald-place, Deptford—the prisoner lodged in the same room and the same bed, and there were two other lodgers, named Beckham and Jones, in the same room—on 9th April I went to bed about 9 o'clock; the prisoner was then in bed—I had 6s. 6d. and a half-crown in my waistcoat pocket, which I put at the foot of the bed—at half-past 4 next morning I missed the money—my pocket was turned inside out and the prisoner was gone—I saw him on the Tuesday following in custody—shortly before I lost my money he had borrowed money in small sums of me and of all the parties in the house, to buy victuals.

JOHN JONES . I lived in the same room with the last witness and the pri
soner—on 10th April I got up at half-past 4; the prisoner had then gone—no other lodger had left; they were all in bed—I found a sovereign and a handkerchief was gone.
JOHN WILLIAM ROBERTS . I keep the King's Arms public-house, Tothill-street, Westminster—on 10th April the prisoner came to me for some

refreshment—he afterwards gave me 20l. to look after for him—he lodged in my house three or four days—I gave up the remainder of the money when the constable came, and also a watch—I have seen the prisoner with a handkerchief like the one produced—he never asked for those articles.

GEORGE BIGGS (Policeman, A 258). I apprehended the prisoner at the Kings Arms on 14th April—I asked him if his name was not Holland—he said it was—he had no boots on, and I asked him where they were—he said he had sold them—I asked him where he lodged, and he said he had no lodging, but had slept in the streets last night—I then told him I appre
hended him for absconding from his lodgings, and stealing 37l—he said he did not take it away—I searched him at the station, but found nothing but an empty purse—I heard his boots were at the house where I apprehended him—I took him there, and asked the barman if he had the boots—he said, "Yes"—I also asked if the prisoner lodged there, and he said, "Yes," and his clothes were up stairs—he then gave me three bundles, and the landlord gave me this handkerchief a silver watch, eleven sovereigns, half a crown, and fourpence—the prisoner did not say anything—when I got him down at Greenwich, he said, before the inspector, "That is my watch."
JOHN WILLIAM BOBBRTS (re-examined.) He deposited with me 20l., and had 3l. back—the remainder he drank and spent and gave away.
Prisoner. I have been regularly in work, and earned a deal of money; I worked hard for it.

GUILTY .—
Confined Eighteen Months.

745.
EDWARD HALL (14), was indicted
for embezzlement MR. LANGFORD conducted the Prosecution.

CHARLES EVENDEN . I am a dairyman, at Plumstead—the prisoner has been in my service about seven weeks—I paid him 2s. 6d. a week, and promised him more if he behaved himself—he had to go for milk to Mr. Holloway, of North Woolwich—we booked it daily, as it was delivered—on 24th February, I think, I gave him 2s. 6d. to buy twelve quarts of milk—I gave him orders to bring back word whether he had paid it—I several times asked him whether he paid it, and he said he had—on the 25th, I gave him 3s. 4d. for sixteen quarts—my wife used to keep my book; it was entered at the time—he said he had paid that—on 26th, I gave him 3s. 4d.—I believe he brought the milk—I frequently asked him if he had paid, and he said, "Yes"—I gave him into custody—he did not say anything—I did not say what money I charged him with taking—I do not know whether I mentioned Holloway's name.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not tell me to say to him you could not send for the milk as it was so bad? A. I never sent any such message—I did not tell you to say I would go over and see him.

STEPHEN HOLLOWAY . I am a cow-keeper, of North Woolwich—on 24th February the prisoner came and asked for twelve quarts of milk, which I gave him—he said his master did not send the money—sometimes he would pay one day and leave a day—he came on the 25th and 26th, and did not pay on those days—I did not ask him any question—I do not recollect his saying the milk was so bad that the customers did not like it—I told him to tell his master he must send the money, or I should not let him have more milk.
JOHN MANGER (Policeman, R 154). I took the prisoner into custody on 13th April.
MARY EVENDEN . I am the wife of Charles Evenden—the entries in the
book (produced) are in my handwriting—the prisoner had those sums to pay for milk.
Prisoner. They never kept a book. Witness. These entries were those entries made; he did not see me enter them.
COURT. to CHARLES EVENDEN. Q. Did he have on the 24th February that precise sum of money? A. The milk came to that—sometimes I would give him three days at once—that would be 7s. 6d.

COURT. to STEPHEN HOLLOWAT. Q. Did the prosecutor pay for three or four days' milk at a time? A. The first week he paid part; then he used to leave a day or two—sometimes it would go on to the amount of 10s. or 12s.—for three or four years previously to that—on 15th March he brought 5s.; I would not let him have any more milk.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: The prisoner was charged upon other indictments with like offences, upon which no evidence was offered.

div1.p:
746.
MARGARET SHEEN (16), and
EDWARD CLARKE (26)
, Un
lawfully attempting to steal 1 florin, the money of
Edward Lee.

JOHN LANGFORD . I live in Trafalgar-road, Greenwich—on 8th April, a little after 4 o'clock, I saw the prisoners with another men and woman drink
ing in the Lord Nelson public-house, Greenwich; soon afterwards Sheen came into my shop—in consequence of something I had heard I followed her out, first to the Victoria and then to the Lord Nelson, where they joined, and on their leaving there I followed them as far as the College—I there pointed them out to Bidgland—I saw no more of them.
Cross-examined by MR. DICKIE. Q. What became of the other two? A. I don't know; they were all four together when I first Saw them—Ridgman is not here; he is too ill to attend.

JOHN LUCAS . I keep a tobacconist's shop on Blackheath-hill—about 8 o'clock on the evening of 8th April Sheen came, for two cigars, and tendered a half-sovereign in payment—I tested it by biting it—upon that she called in Clarke, and said, "Ned, this man has bent your half-sovereign"—I said, "If I have, and it is a good one, I will give you change"—the man made a bit of a bother—he said, "Come up to the jeweller's and have it tested"—we went to a jeweller's, and it was found to be a good one—we then returned to the shop, and I gave 9s. 9d. change—the two cigars came to 3d.—Clarke refused to take the cigars and his 9s. 9d., and wanted another half-sovereign instead of the one I had bent—I refused to give him another one, and eventually he took the change and the cigars, and they left.

EDWIN BOTTRELL . I keep the Fisherman's Arms, Greenwich—on the night of 8th April, about half past 9, the two prisoners and another woman came, and called for a pint of ale; my brother served them, and gave them change for a half-sovereign—Sheen asked for two bottles of ginger-beer to take away with her, and gave a half-sovereign in payment—my brother gave her two half-crowns and 4s. change—as soon as she had got the change in her hand she said she wanted three bottles—I said I did not keep them—she then wanted her half-sovereign back, and she put 8s. on the counter instead of 9s.—I distinctly saw the other shilling in her hand; my brother asked her for the other shilling—she said, "That is all you gave me"—my brother caught hold of her hand, and she dropped it on the onside of the counter—as soon as Sheen bad got the change, Clarke and the other woman left—I went and brought Clarke back, and charged him with being con
nected
with her—he denied knowing anything of her till, we got to the door, and then he said, "Give my girl the half-sovereign back."

JEREMIAH HENESST (Policeman, R 192). I was called to Mr. Lucas's, and found the prisoners there, disputing about a half-sovereign—I saw Sheen take up the change, 9s. 9d.—Clarke said, "What the b—y h—i do you think we stole it; what me and my sister had to work hard for all the, week"—from there I saw the two prisoners go into the George and Dragon with another woman, and afterwards to the Coach and Horses, and the Duke of York; they then all went into the Banshee beer-shop—I was after
wards called to the Fisherman's Arms, where I received the prisoners in charge from Mr. Bottrell for attempting to steal a shilling.
Cross-examined. Q. What became of the other female? A. She was taken into custody, but was discharged.

SHEEN—
GUILTY .—
Confined One Month.

CLARKE—
GUILTY .*—
Confined Six Months.

747.
ELLEN MURPHY (30),
PLEADED GUILTY
to stealing 5lbs. of bacon, the goods of
William Benjamin Blackmoare.—
Confined Twelve Months.

748.
ELIZA CALBREATH (18),
PLEADED GUILTY
to stealing, on 25th April, 2s., the money of
Thomas Langley.—
Confined Twelve Months.

749.
HENRY FLOWERS(15),
PLEADED GUILTY
to embezzling 1s. on 19th April; 4s. on 20th and 10 1/2 d. on 25th April, the moneys of
Thomas Clark, his master.—
Confined Fourteen Days, and
to be detained in Red Hill Reformatory, for three Years.

750.
JOHN THOMAS (36),
PLEADED GUILTY
to stealing 4 lbs. 6ozs. of cocoa, value 2s. 6d., the property of
Her Majesty.—
Confined Six Months.

751.
CHARLES WILLIAM SMITH (59),
PLEADED GUILTY
to forging and uttering a promissory note, for 5l., with intent to defraud.—
Confined Twelve Months.

752.
ELIZA MATTINGLEY (32),
PLEADED GUILTY
to stealing 2 dresses, 1 umbrella, and other articles, value 30s., the property of
Thomas Pacey Birts, her master.—
Confined Four Months .

753.
HENRY HARRIS (26)
, Feloniously carnally knowing and abusing
Mercy Rebecca Proudfoot, a girl under 10 years of age.

MR. SLEIGH conducted the Prosecution, and MR. LILLET the Defence.—
GUILTY of the attempt .—
Confined Eighteen Months .

754.
JOSEPH HARYEY (23)
PLEADED GUILTY
to stealing 60 pairs of ear-rings, and other articles, in a dwelling-house; also, to stealing sheets, and other articles, of
Martha Adams, in her dwelling-house also, to stealing 1 breast—pin, ear-rings, and other articles, value 150l. of
William Collins, in his dwelling-house; also, to stealing and receiving 100 yards of 3 coats, and 3 waistcoats.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

755.
JOHN CROCKETT (24)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

MBSSBS. POLAND
and ORRIDGE conducted the Prosecution, MR. BRST defended.

ANNIE PRICK . I live with my father, John Price, who keeps the Welling
ton Arms, Waterloo-road—on 25th April, between 4 and 5, the prisoner came with four women and asked for a pot of ale—he paid with a half-crown—I looked at it and told him it was bad—he said, "I will give you another," and he gave me half a crown, which I saw was likewise bad—I then sent for a constable—one of the women then snatched the money out of the prisoner's left hand, and they all four ran away—the prisoner bad been drinking slightly.

Cross-examined by MR. BEST. Q. He was drunk was he not? A. I should not say he was drunk—he was leaning on the counter—he did not say any
thing.
MR. ORRIDGE. Q. To whom did you give the shilling and half-crown? A. To the constable.

JOHN COLLINS (Policeman, K 184). I was sent for to the Wellington Arms, and prisoner was given into custody—the last witness gave me a shilling and half-crown (produced)—I found this bad florin in prisoner's left hand—at the station I searched him, and found half a crown and three shillings good money in his trousers pocket—I told him the half-crown was a bad one; he made no reply—he had the appearance of having been drink
ing—he knew what he was about.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he give his correct name and address? A. Yes.
WILLUM WEBSTIR . The coins produced are counterfeit.

GUILTY .—
Confined Nine Months.

756.
EMMA CLARK (25), was indicted
for a like offence. MESSRS. POLAND and ORRIDGE conducted the Prosecution.

ELIZA ARNOLD . I am a clerk in the telegraph office, 68, London-road—on 24th April, the prisoner came to my office at about 11 in the morning, with a message to be forwarded, but it was retained for non-delivery—the person to whom it was directed was not found—she paid half a crown, the message was 6d.—I gave her the 2s. and put the half-crown in the till—she came again about half-past 2 on the same day, and then gave me a message to send—I did not forward that—she paid with a half a crown—I sent it to be changed next door by McDonald—he brought it back and I then told the prisoner it was bad—she said she should not think of passing a bad one—I examined the till while she was there, and found three more bad half-crowns—I bad other silver in the till, but the bad half-crowns were all lying at the top—I cannot tell exactly at what time I received those without looking at the messages—there was one at 1.25, another at 1.35, and the prisoner came first about 11—those were not the only messages I took that day, but the only ones paid by half-crowns—I told the prisoner the half crown was bad, and that she had been before that morning—she denied it—I gave the half-crowns to the constable—I am quite sure she had been at the office—the two messages produced, I received between 11 and the prisoner coming—the other two (produced) I took from prisoner—they all four appear to be written by the same person.
WILLIAM MCDONALD . I am a messenger in the telegraph office, London road—on 24th April, I received from last witness a half-crown which I took
next door to get changed—it was tried in my presence and returned to me—I took it back to Miss Arnold.

DAVID HATTERSLEY (Policeman, P 292). I took the prisoner into custody on 24th April—Miss Arnold gave me a half-crown which I produce—the pri
soner was searched, and two sixpences good money were found upon her.
WILLIAM WERSITER The half-crowns produced are all bad.

Prisoner's Defence. I went out about quarter past 2 and I met a gentle-man. He told me if I would take a message to the telegraph office ha would give me a shilling. I took the Message, and when I gave in the piece of paper I gave half a crown; this young person put it down where there was some other money, and then she took it up and said it was bad; she accused me of going there at 11. I never left my home until a quarter-past 2, and I met the gentleman at half-past 2. He gave ma a half crown, and said I was to bring back 2s. and pay 6d. for the message; I had no idea it was bad.

GUILTY —
Confined Twelve Months.

757.
MARIA FROST (37), and
ELIZABETH MASON (42)
, Feloniously administering to
Frederick Wyatt, a certain stupifying thing; to enable them to steal his purse and money.

FREDERICK WYATT . I am living now at Liverpool—I was, on the 24th April, staying at 59, Victoria-terrace, Union-road, Southwalk—on that day I met a woman in Newington-causeway, and went with her to 17, Revel's-row, but she did not stop—I saw prisoners there with a third wonsan, who got away—they asked me what I would give them to drink, and I gave them a shilling twice to get rum, of which I drank about a quarter of a glass—when I had been there about three-quarters of an hour, the one that got away forced me on to a bed and put her hand to my face; one was on one aide and one on another, and Mason held my feet—I was completely senseless, though I could see everything they were doing—I am quite confident the two prisoners were in the room—there was 8l. in gold, and about 11s. in silver in my pockets—Frost took the money out of my right side pocket—they knew the money I had with me—the party I went with told ma to take care what money I had got, and I counted the whole of my money which they saw—previously to forcing me on the bed, they used a white handkerchief to me that had chloroform, of which I know the smell quite well—I was paralysed—I remained helpless after that—it was between 5 and 6 before I came to myself—I went to the police-station at half-past 6.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Where do you live? A. I arrived. in Liverpool on 3d February, from Smyrna, and I had then been stopping at 59, Victoria-terrace, but I am no stranger in London—I have been in the Ottoman Empire the last three years—! was only visiting them—my business is connected with railways—I am here under a doctor's certificate for the benefit of my health—I was in the fourth division of the London police before I went to Asia Minor—I left that to go to the South Eastern Railway—I left of my own accord—I resigned—I remained with the South Eastern Railway about eighteen months—I then left to better myself, of my own accord—I have merely come home from Asia Minor on account of the fever—that is the only cause—I have had money offered to me to forego this prosecution by five or six people, but I have not offered to take any—I have not offered to take 3l—I do not know Sally Brown or Sally Bishop—I did not offer to her to take 3l.—I did not draw up a paper, which I proposed to send to the Magistrate in case I received a certain sum, saying I would not proceed with the prosecution—there was a paper of that

sort handed to me, but it was not my conditions at all—I saw that paper, but I did not accept of it—I did not show it to Hussey, the pot man—I have been offered money, but I would not take it, on certain conditions—I do not think it was likely I should say, I would go right away if I got a certain sum of money; I was bound in 40l. to appear—I never made that offer in the presence of' Hussey—I know a woman who goes by the name of Mrs. White—I did not say to her, I would accept 3l. to forego this prosecution—I had been to the house in question before—I went there between 3 and 4—I gave Frost 2s. to get drink twice, giving her 1s. on each occasion—no one else went for drink—there were three women in my com
pany when the robbery occurred—there was one before, but she did not stop long, only about five minutes—I did not remain with her half an hour; she did not give me her company—she merely came to the door, and went inside, and spoke to me, and went away—I found the prisoners there when I went, and another woman came about ten minutes after I arrived there—she did not come at my request—she remained about a quarter of an hour—I bad seen her face before, bat do not know her name; she was the one who contrived with the two prisoners to rob me—it was nearly six when I left—I had not been into any public-house before I went—I had taken a glass of half-and-half for dinner at my sister's—I had nothing in addition—it is some years ago since I acquired my experience of chloroform; I have smelt it—I have never inhaled it; nor undergone any operation which rendered it necessary—I knew Dr. McCree some years ago, and have taken out a bottle, and smelt It—I should think the day in question was the second time I have been in this house since I have been in this country—I went out to Asia Minor in October, 1860—I saw five persons during the time I was in this house.
MR. DICKIE. Q. Is there any pretence for saying you were tipsy when in this house? A. None whatever; the officer will prove I was quite sober.

WILLIAM CUMMING (Policeman, M 196). On 24th April I went to the house of prisoner Frost, at 17, Revel's-row, at 7 o'clock—I did now see her then—at 8 o'clock I saw her there with Mason—I told her I wanted her for robbing a man of a quantity of money—I commenced searching the place, and she said, "It is no use, you won't find it"—I said, "Find what?"—she replied, "Nothing"—I had another constable, I told him to take Mason, and she ran up stairs.

LOT SAWYER (Policeman, M 175). I went with the last witness to take the prisoners into custody on the 24th April—I saw them both—Mason ran up stairs, and I followed her, and I saw her breaking the string of a new pair of foots—I asked what she had got, and she said she had bought them the day before in Suffolk-street—I told her I should take her into custody for being concerned in robbing Mr. Wyatt—I took her to the station, and afterwards went to Mr. Durrant's with the other constable, and made inquiries about some boots—I afterwards made inquiries at the Skinner's Arms, and I saw the witness, Hussey.

COURT. Q. Did you see the prosecutor before yon went? A. I did between 7 and 8—he was the worse for drink; he had been drinking, by his appearance—I did go near enough to smell if it was anything except drink.

WILLIAM DURRANIT . I am a shoemaker, of 21, Great Suffolk-street, Borough—on 24th April, Frost bought a pair of boots of me—I have known her for several years; she has regularly dealt with us—it was in the afternoon she had the boots—I cannot say exactly the time—in the
evening she came with somebody else, and bought a pair of boot for 3s. 9d.,—she gave me 4s., and I gave her 3d. back—these (produced) are the boots.

WILLIAM HUSSEY . I am barman at the Skinner's Arms public-house, Great Suffolk-street, Borough—I remember Frost coming in on the 24th April, about 5 in the afternoon—she gave me a sovereign and a half, and asked me to put it on the shelf; and mind it for her—I did not see the officer, it was my master.

Cross-examined. Q. Hare you seen the prosecutor since this matter? A. Yes—on one occasion he showed me a paper that he had written out—he said he intended to present it to the Magistrate, wishing to withdraw the case—on several occasions he has asked parties round to make up a sum of money to withdraw from the case, as he wished to have nothing at all to do with it, and he would go away, and keep away altogether until such time as it was over—I, have heard him offers to accept money for the purpose of going away on several occasions—it is a very common case that we have money left with us by various people to take care of—Frost has before deposited money with my master, but not with me.

MR. DICKIE. Q. Have you not offered to pawn your watch to get Frost out trouble, and give the money to the prosecutor? A. Never—I said yesterday if it was possible to get Counsel to plead for both, as I had not the means in my possession, then I would pawn my watch to get the money, if I thought the parties would pay me back—I have known Frost three years as coming to our house—the prosecutor told me that he wrote that statement.
NOT GUILTY .

758.
EDWIN ROGERS (24)
, Stealing 6 window-sashes, and other property, the goods of
John Thomas Peacock, fixed to a building.

WILLIAM WINTER . I am a cheesemonger, living at Lower-road, Islington—I became possessed of the house No. 4, Corthorpe-terrace, Bermondsey-new-road, from the Governors of St. Thomas's Hospital, and Mr. Booth by a lease for twenty-one years, and I occupied under that lease—when it was granted I laid out a sum of money in fitting up the place for the business of a cheese
monger—I put in a new counter, new gas-fittings, and new mahogany sashes, plate-glass, new shelves, and deal lining—the whole cost me 95l——there was not a leaden cistern in the yard—on 13th August, I sold the good—will and fixtures, and assigned the lease to the prisoner—the assignment it endorsed on the back of the lease (produced)—I have seen the prisoner there, carrying on business under that assignment.

THOMAS ABBOTT . I am assistant messenger in the Court of Bankruptcy—I produce the proceedings in the bankruptcy of the prisoner, and of Anthony Voght—the prisoner's petition is dated 26th July, 1862, and the adjudication is 29th July, 1862—the appointment of the prosecutor as creditor's assignee is 19th of August, 1862—those proceedings are still pending—Anthony Voght filed two petitions, one on 12th March, 1863, and the second, the 14th March.

BENJAMIN MARSLAND . I am articled clerk to Mr. Sheene, of Harp-lane, Lower-street, solicitor—I have been collector of the rent for No. 4, Cor
thorpe-terrace, Bermondsey-new-road, for the superior landlord under the lease—I had occasion to go constantly to the shop during the latter part of last year—the prisoner was present—I was there in the middle of February—the shop was then quite complete with counter and lining, and gas-fittings

—there was a pair of scales and set of weights and marble-blocks, and all the fittings of a cheesemonger—I called one Saturday evening in February, I think the 14th, about the rent—the prisoner could not pay, and he got into a terrible pet, swore very badly, and said be would cut every b—y thing to pieces—on the Monday morning I went round to levy a distress, and the place was shut up.

JOHN THOMAS PEACOCK . I am an egg merchant, carrying on business in Berwick-street, Oxford-street, and I was appointed creditors' assignee, under the prisoner's bankruptcy—I endeavoured to obtain possession of property in his order and disposition—objection was made to my taking this lease—I cannot say precisely what was said—as to the fixtures you will see what was seized by the bill of sale—they were claimed by the prisoner's father—the prisoner did not say anything to me about it—it is in evidence in the Court of Bankruptcy—I took proceedings against Anthony Voght—the prisoner was present at the trial, which took place, I believe, on the 15th of December last year—I recovered a verdict—I endeavoured after the action to get possession of this place and the fixtures at the latter part of April—I then found the premises completely gutted—no one was in the place, and I effected an entrance, breaking in—I found a cistern had been removed—I did not notice whether the ballcock was gone the window
sashes and gas fittings were taken away.

GEORGE CARTER I am a furniture dealer, living at Pitt-street, old Kent-road—I was employed by the prisoner some time in February to go to 4, Cortbope-terrace, Bermondsey-new-road, and I went—we assisted in moving away the fittings of the shop, the counter, weights, gas fittings, and sashes with plate-glass—I did not take what is called the match boarding—I did not notice whether it had been taken down—I took the things away in a barrow to my place, and they were from there on the same day—on first removing the things some were taken out at the front way, and some the back way, over a wall, and through another house, and then by a back street—they were removed by me to Mr. Hill's—he made the bargain with the prisoner—I had nothing to do with that.

JOHN HILL . I am a dealer in fixtures of New-cut. Lambeth—in February last the prisoner came with some one to me, and brought some scales, gas-fittings, a few match-board deals, a butter-block, and two mahogany sashes, fitted with plate-glass—I think I gave him 5l. or 6l. for the first lot—I produce a receipt for 4l. 10s—the window-sashes came at two different times—I think I gave him about 11l. altogether.

FREDERICK INDERMAUR . I am an auctioneer and value, carrying on business in Union-street, Southwark—on 16th April I examined the pro
mises 4, Cortherpe-terrace—I went to distrain, but could not get in—they were in a very dilapidated state—the counter was gone—the lining-board had been removed—some portion was left on, and others had been wrenched off—I did not notice any cistern, or the place where there should have been one.

p.hi: was Of opinion that the indictment for felony could not be supported, at there was lawful possession, and no determination, of the tenancy, and directed a verdiet of

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

759.
EDWIN ROGERS was again indicted
for unlawfully pulling down from a freehold house certain fixtures.
WILLAM WINTER . (The evidence of ibis witness in the former case was read over). I have seen the premises since April—there was nothing in

them at all—the damage had bean done inside—I saw the damage done by the water, in consequence of the removal of the cistern—it was cut off from the pipe—I did not see any water—there was a ball-cock when I took the shop.

BENJAMIN MARSLAND . (The evidence of this witness in the former case was read over). On the 15th April, when I got possession of the place, the cistern had been removed, and the water had flooded the place ankle-deep,—there was nothing in the shop, the lining had been torn down reck
lessly—it was a perfect wreck, and the damage would be a considerable amount—the water poured in when turned on from the main.

GEORGE CARTER . (The former evidence of this witness was read over.) I went to the premises more than once—I could not take all the things in one barrow—there was nothing taken down while I was there-three out of the four panes of glass in the frame were sound, one was cracked—I took down the gas-fittings and counter, but not the match boarding—as regards what I did I had no trouble—I helped to take the water cistern down—the pipe was bent up to prevent the water flowing.
THOMAS ABBOTT . (The evidence of this witness in the former case was read over)

FREDERICK INDERMAUR . (The former evidence of this witness was read over I did not see any water in the premises—the boarding was removed in quite the reverse of workman-like manner—it was torn out—it was pulled down not merely carelessly, but wantonly—I should think the whole damage would be 40l. or 50l.

Prisoner's Defence. I thought I had a right to take the things; I paid 500l. for the shop, and I lost about 600l.; I was awfully taken in. If I have done wrong I am willing to work; hard to pay it back.
NOT GUILTY .

760.
JAMES FREDERICKS (27)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
Samuel Upham Whittel, and stealing 1 pair of trousers, and other articles, the property of
Henry Madge.

HENRY MADGE . I am a salesman at Messrs. Perks, Shad Thames, and live at 18, Trinity-square, in the house of Mr. Whittel, in the parish of St. Mary, Newington—on the morning of 10th April I left my home as usual, and, I believe, I left in the chest of drawers in my room, four waist-coats, two shirts, and other articles—t afterwards saw a portion of them at, the station-house—I returned home at half-past I on the morning of the 11th, and found my room in a general state of confusion—it is on the first-floor back a bedroom—the drawers were emptied, and the clothes scattered all about the room—I did not examine sufficiently to miss any articles at that time—I called the servant—I Afterwards saw the prisoner in custody at the police-station, and these articles (produced), which are mine—the pri
soner had some of the things on—I believe they were taken from him at the police-station.

Prisoner. Did yon not say when yon came to the station that you believed those were the clothes, and that if they were they would be marked? A. Yes—I examined the shirt—I did not notice any marks, but I did not examine it thoroughly—I did not know at the time where they were marked—I asked to take the shirt home with me to compare it with some that I had—I was not half an hour away, I believe—I will swear I brought back

the same shirt—I do not know whether the flannel was marked—I said I should know the black trousers by a kind of mark at the bottom—I swear that all these articles are mine—I have not said that I held the person as he was coming out, or that I saw his face—I saw you passing hastily—I could not swear to you—I said there was stitching at the bottom of the trousers of a particular kind before I looked at them—the policeman examined them and found the stitching, and upon that I swore to them.

CHARLOTTE BEECHING . I am servant to Mr. Whittel, of 18, Trinity-square—on 10th April, we went to bed at twenty minutes to 11—I made the house secure, in the usual way; we are rather careless—the front kitchen window was closed; I cannot say it was fastened—the window-shutters were to, and a desk and work-box were against the shutters—I went into Mr. Madge's room as I went up stairs, and it was perfectly straight, as usual—at about 2 o'clock—I was called up—I went down stairs, found the kitchen shutters were open, and the work-box and desk on the floor, and the contents turned out—there was a mark on the area railings, as if some one had put their foot over and come down the wall; there are no steps or gate to the area—if a person got into the area, he had nothing to do but throw up the window to get in—I afterwards went into the front parlour—I looked under the table, and there was a man there—there was light enough for me to perceive that he was in his shirt sleeves, and had no shoes on—he rushed past me to the front door, which was open, and rushed out—I do not know who had opened the front door.

Prisoner. Q. What time was it when you were awoke? A. As near as I can guess, about a quarter to 2—about twenty minute* elapsed from my first being awaked to the person leaving the house—I was up stairs, looking over the place.

JOHN POMERT (Policeman, M 130). On the morning of the 11th April, I was on duty in Trinity-square—I heard a cry of "Police," and went to No. 18, and first went into the front kitchen—in the parlour I found four waistcoats and two shirts, which had been conveyed there from the bedroom—those were afterwards claimed by Mr. Madge—I went to Mr. Madge's room, and found a coat, two dirty shirts, and a pair of blucher boots there—Mr. Madge, at the police-station, first told me the articles found were his; then he afterwards said, "Let me hare them and put them on"—they fitted him pretty well—I had ordered the prisoner to take them off—in the pocket of the prisoner's clothes I found a seaman's discharge, and some matches—when I took the prisoner to the station-house, he had on some of the prosecutor's' clothes.

Prisoner. Q. Did you accompany Mr. Madge to the station-house? A. I did—I said, "Here he is"—from the description Mr. Madge gave to me, I told him to come to the station-house, and most probably he would see the man—the description was, a person going away without shoes and stockings, in his shirt sleeves, and without a hat—you were ordered to take off the clothes, and he tried to find a name on them, but without success—he then asked for the shirt to take home and compare with the others—the shirt did not go out of my sight—the mark on the shirt I did look for, but it was almost invisible—there was a gas light there—Mr. Madge said he had every reason to believe the articles were his.

DAVID DAVIS (Policeman, A 473). At half-past 2, on the 11th April, I heard a cry of "Stop thief," and saw a person running down New Kent road, from St. George's-road and Trinity-square—it is some distance from Trinity-square—I sprung my rattle, and ran across the road, and caught

the prisoner, who was in his shirt sleeves, and without a hat or boots—he said, "For God's sake, don't stop me, policeman; I am a seaman, and have been robbed"—I hit him with my rattle, and there is some of his blood on the shirt—I took him to the station-house.

WILLIAM DUFFEL (Policeman, M 151). At half-past 2, on 11th April, I saw the prisoner jump over the sash window of No. 43, St. George's-road—I followed him, and never lost sight of him until he was secured and taken back.

CHARLOTTE MAYNARD . I heard a noise in my bedroom at about a quarter-past 2, on 11th April—I know it Was that time, because I looked at the clock when the officer brought back the prisoner to my house.

Prisoner's Defence. I went to the music-hall with a couple of females, and after I left I suddenly became insensible, and I remember no more until I found myself in the room of the last witness. She asked, "Who is there?" I said, "I am a sailor, who has been robbed." I tried to get out; the door was locked, and I jumped out of window. The trousers and waistcoat I claim as my own property.
GUILTY .
The prisoner was further charged with having been formerly convicted of felony, on 31st March, at Kingston-upon-Thames; to which he

PLEADED GUILTY.**—
Six Years' Penal Servitude.

761.
JOHN BROWN (27), and
CHARLES KEMBLE (22),
Stealing 3 rings, value 7l., the property of
John Trafalgar Black, in his dwelling-house.

MARIAN BLACK. I am the wife of John Trafalgar Black, a tutor, of 4, Hamilton-place, Brixton-road—on 27th April, the prisoners came—my servant let them into the dining-room, and then into the drawing-room—I followed them, and asked them what apartment they wanted—they said a dewing-room floor and two bedrooms—they told me they were professional singers, engaged at different houses, and that they kept a "trap"—I showed them the drawing-room floor; there was no property of mine them—the servant then took them to this second-floor—my bedroom is on that floor, Over the drawing-room—I heard some one overhead, in my room—the servant then brought them down—they said there was another professional singer, and wished to know what other bedroom I could let them have—knowing that they had been in my room, I suspected them, and directed my servant to show her bedroom, to give me time—they went up stairs again, and I ran up to my bedroom, and missed three rings, which I had left on the looking-glass, worth 6l. or 7l.—I then came down, and waited at the drawing-room door until the prisoners came down—I went into the ball before them—they said the apartment would suit them very well—I said, "I wish to speak to you; step into the dining-room for a minute,"—they said their time was up, and they must go—I said, "I cannot allow you to go until you have given me the three rings which you have taken from my bedroom"—I put the chain on the front door—they were then in the hall, coming towards the door—I stood before them, and would not let them pass—they said, "Oh, dear no, madam; the very idea of such a thing! we are too respectable; we have never been guilty of such a thing"—I said, "You have them"—there was a life-preserver hanging on the folding-door between the front and back room; Kemble took it off the door—I said, "You had better give me up the rings; what do you intend doing f you will be trans
ported; if you have no fear of man, have you no fear of God? if yon give me up the rings, I will release you"—there was a friend of nine down Stairs—I called him up—as he was coming up, the prisoners said, "If you

look round the room, you will find your property"—I had seen Brown put something on the sofa, and I said, "I saw where you put them"—he then took the three rings between his thumb and finger, brought them to me, and said, "Now you have got your property, you will allow us to go"—I said, "No"—I thought I saw the life-preserver in one of the prisoners' pocket—it had been lying on the table when my friend came up, and one of them took it off—they refused to give up the rings until the police were at the door.

Cross-examined by MR. DICKIE. (For Brown) Q. Had you sent for a policeman? A. Yes, I had sent my servant, and heard her putting the key in the door—the moment they heard footsteps, Brown dropped the rings—the door was opened by my friend, and there were the servant and two policemen.

Cross-examined by MR. SMITH. (For Kamble). Q. When they came to the house, I suppose you thought them respectable? A. I had my doubts—I let my servant show them over the premises instead of going with them—there was no property in the bed-room which the servant showed them—her room is on the third floor, and mine is on the second floor—Kemble was the one that took the life-preserver—there was no attempt to strike me—I said if they gave up the rings I would let them go, because I thought it would give me time to send for a policeman—perhape when I made that promise I had the intention of breaking it—I intended to see whether they had robbed me of my property—when you have thieves in the house you do the best you can.

Dickie. Q. Did yon ever say anything about the life-preserver before to
day? A. I did to the policeman—I was not asked about it before the Magis
trate—it was taken off the door in my presence—it was not attempted to be used—I am certain I saw the rings when last in my room—I had taken them off to wash my hands.
MR. PALMER. Q. Had you any other motive in making the promise but the laudable strategy of gaining time? A. No.

WILLIAM LAKE (Policeman, P 264). I was called, and look the prisoners at Hamilton-place—they made no statement—they were given in charge for stealing the rings—they gave a false address—there was another constable.

Kemble received a good character.—
GUILTY .—
Four Years' Penal Servitude each.

p.hi: There were several other similar indictments against the prisoners.

div1.p:
762.
FRANCIS WELDMAN (30),
PLEADED GUILTY
to forging and utter
ing a request for the payment of 3s., with intent to defraud.

763.
JOHN GARRATT (41)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

EMMA KINGSFORD . I am waitress at a coffee-house, 10, Duke-street, Southwark—on the morning of the 8th April, about half-past 1, the pri
soner came in and had some provisions to the amount of 7 1/2 d.—he gave me a half-crown, and I gave him Is. 10 1/2 d. change—I put the half-crown in my pocket—I had no other there—the prisoner went away, and in about twenty minutes he came in again, ordered similar provisions, and gave me another half-crown; I looked at it, saw it was bad, and told him so—he said it was a good one—I sent for my master, and took the other one out of my pocket and found that was also bad—I gave them both to my master—the prisoner was given into custody—he said he did not know the money was bad.

GEORGE WALTER SMITH , I keep the coffee-house, 10, Duke-street—on 8th April the last witness gave me two bad half-crowns; I sent for a con
stable, and gave the prisoner in charge, with the half-crowns.

ROBERT PIERCEY (Policeman, M 299). I took the prisoner—I produce two half-crowns, which I got from Mr. Smith—I found 3 1/2 d. in coppers on the prisoner—I asked him his address, and he refused to tell me.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These half-crowns are both bad.

GUILTY .—
Confined Four Months.

764.
ELIZABETH TANN(17),
PLEADED GUILTY
to stealing a box con
training jewellery to the value of 1,000l., the property of
Fanny Josephs.

765.
JAMES FRENCH (42) and
THOMAS DAVIS BELL (32), were indicted for
a conspiracy.

JACOB FITCHETT . I am a traveller in the employ of Messrs. Sears and Co.—the firm, I believe, consists of two persons—I knew French some years ago, but had lost sight of him several years—early in April he came into the Duke of Clarence public-house, where I was, and said that he wanted about 20l. worth of wine—I took him over to my stores, and introduced him to my stock-manager, Mr. Vickers—some wine was tasted, and an order was given to the amount of 40l.—he said that he was a provision—dealer, and wanted it for captains, to facilitate business—Mr. Vickers asked him for a reference, stating that the terms were cash and discount, or a bill at three months—when we left the stores I told him that it was a larger amount than I felt justified in executing, and he said that he would leave it in my hands to reduce it to the amount previously stated, 20l.—we went to the Duke of Clarence again, and an arrangement was made that I should meet him at the Black Prince, Waterloo-road—I did so on Wednesday, and the first thing he said was, "What is the reason my order is not executed?"—I said, "You said that you could give a reference, and we have had no name give to us"—he said, "Oh, my dear fellow, I can give you forty," but he mentioned no name—he asked me bow I should be situated the following morning, and I appointed to meet him at Aldgate Church—I did so, and we proceeded to High-street, Whitechapel—he did not mention the name of any reference during the walk, but when we got within a few steps of the premises of Merry and Nutter, I saw a person of the appearance of a gentleman, standing on the steps, leaning against the doorpost, with a pen behind his ear—French said "There is Mr. Henry Nutter; wait while I speak to him"—he went up to the person, topped with him half a minute, and then turned back to me, and said, "Mr. Nutter will tell you all that you require."—I went up to the gentle-man, and said, "Mr. Nutter, I presume?"—he nodded—I repeated the ques
tion, and he said, "That is my name"—I asked him if Mr. French was trust
worthy to the amount of 20l. or 30l.—he said, "Perfectly"—I said "He might be, in the provision line, but would he be for a luxury?"—he said, "What do you call a luxury?"—I said, "Wine"—he said, "Perfectly, for we as fre
quently owe him money as he does us," that he was perfectly solvent, and we need not have the slightest fear—I returned, and made a report to Mr. Vickers.

Cross-examined by MR. LANGFORD. Q. Would you have sent the 20l. worth, without a reference? A. No—agreed to send it—I met French on the Tuesday at the Black Prince, in the Walworth-road, and he asked me why the wine was not delivered—I only know Mr. Lansdale by meeting him at the Duke of Clarence—I went to his house with the detective after the

prisoners were given in custody, and asked Mr. Lansdale to give me a copy of the invoice, but did not get it—I was not present when the bill watt given—French did not tell me to go and make the inquiries of Nutter, but I thought that was the person he intended as a reference.

MR. TILLEY. Q. Did he say, "That is Mr. Nutter, who will tell yon all that you require?" A. Yes; I sent directions from Vickers—I did not know Lonsdale when we first met at the Duke of Clarence—I met him at the Black Prince the following Wednesday week—French said, "Mr. Lansdale will become a reference as well"—Bell came to the stores in King's Arms-yard with a horse and cart, to take the things away.

MR. LANGFORD. Q. Did not you meet French again at the Black Prince when the bill was accepted? A. Yes; I said that the bill had not arrived, and be said that he had sent it by post that very day—I never made in
quiries of Lonsdale—when I say that it was agreed to send the wine, I mean subject to the reference—it was a private understanding of ours that we should not deliver it without a reference, but French did not understand that.

JOHN VICKERS . I am manager of the stores of Levaux & Co. King's-Arms-yard, Tooley-street—about 8th or 10th April, French came with Fitehett—French proposed to buy some wine, and said that his object in coming to us was, that he should get something good for the particular class of trade which he had, the provision trade; as it was to give to parties with whom he was doing business, to tempt his customers to business—he mentioned captains—he gave me an order amounting to about 40l.—I said that I could not undertake it unless he gave us satisfactory references—he said that he should be able to give most satisfactory references—on 6th January, I desired Fitehett to inquire into the character of the supposed references, and some days afterwards he made a report to me in consequence of which I allowed the goods to be delivered—it had been reduced to 23l. or 24l. at that time—he gave me this card (produced) when he was intro
duced—Bell is the person to whom the goods were delivered on 16th April—he produced a card similar to the one French gave me, in consequence of which I gave directions to the warehouseman—I did not see the wine delivered, but two dozen only were delivered at first, as I was very busy—I was present the second time Bell came, but did not see any part of the goods delivered to him—I saw a bottle of wine at the police-office—I did not taste it, but from its peculiar structure and seal I had no doubt it was mine—after the order was executed, French came again, and we arranged to take a bill at three months, on the presumption that the references were right—the bill (produced) was drawn in our counting-house and forwarded on the Tuesday to the address on the card which French gave, and it after
wards returned accepted—we acknowledged it, and afterwards received back from the Post-office this envelope of our letter, marked "Gone away; not known where."

WILLIAM BACK . I am clerk to Messrs. Levaux—on 16th April, I delivered two dozen of wine by Mr. Vickers' direction to Bell, who produced a card which I gave to Mr. Vickers—he signed "J. Henderson" to the counterfoil of the delivery note in my presence—he came again on 15th April, and I delivered ten dozen, for which he signed another counterfoil "J. Henderson."

EBENEZER BUILDER . I am clerk to Merry & Nutter of Whitechapel, whole
sale provision merchants in a large way of business—there is not only no Mr. Henry Nutter in the firm, but no Mr. Nutter—I have no knowledge of French—my position is such, that if he was a customer I should be aware of it.

ALFRED WATERER . I am a house-agent, of Alma Cottage, Commercial-road, Peckham—I have the letting of 16, Cottage Grove, which is near the Duke of Sussex, Commercial-road, the front of which is in Park-road—Bell

took the house at the end of February for twelve months, and entered into occupation a day or two afterwards—he told me that he belonged to the Customs—he was dressed quite like a gentleman—I found the house vacant about 23d April—I had not received any notification from Bell of his leaving—he paid me no rent—he gave the name of John French.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you quite certain it was Bell who took the house? A. I have not the least doubt of him—I was satisfied with his re
ferences—he called on me one day, and wanted to come into the house the following day, as he had got a fortnight's leave—I saw him, very respectably dressed, doing up the front garden, a fortnight after he entered into occupa
tion, and did not see him again till he was in the police-court.

WILLIAM CHILD . I am assistant to a Sheriff's officer—for certain reasons I watched No. 16, Cottage Grove, Peckham, for about a week before 23d April—I saw Bell go in three times, and French three or four times—I also saw Lansdale go in with French several times—the house was closed on Thursday morning, the 23d at 6 o'clock.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you A. Assistant to Mr. Jackson, the Sheriff of London—I have been with him about two months before that—I was an officer at Red Lion Wharf for about sixteen months, and before that I was an officer of the City of London—I was beadle of Trinity-square twenty years—I have never been charged at the Mansion-house with perjury, or anything else—I was watching this house for the Loan Society people, Lisson Grove—I made no communication to Messrs. Levaux—I happened to be at the Court, and saw the prisoner brought up.

ROBERT MARTIN . I am landlord of the Duke of Sussex, Cumberland-road, Peckham—I saw French at the police-station, and fancied I had seen him in the house one day—Lonsdale came to my house two or three times a week—he brought me twenty-three bottles of port and sherry to sell; it was then that 1 fancy I saw French there, but I did not speak to him—I do not know that I saw Bell; but there were several in the bar, as I have an ordinary at 1 o'clock—the wine was on the kitchen table when I came in—I bought twenty-one bottles, and afterwards sold one bottle of the port to Broderick, the constable—two bottles were opened as samples, and drank by Lonsdale, myself, and two friends.

JOHN BRODERICK (Policeman, M 210). I produce a bottle of wine which I bought of Martin—I showed it to Mr. Vickers—I took French on 1st May—he' was with Lonsdale, in Brunswick-street, Blackfriars-road—he at tempted to run away, but I overtook him—I told him the charge was conspiring to defraud Messrs. Vickers & Co. of 25l. worth of wine, and asked if his name was French—he said, "No; I do not know anybody of that name"—I took him as far as Lonsdale's shop—he wanted to go in there, but I would not allow him—I took him to the station—the inspector asked him his name—he said, "French"—I took Bell about a quarter-past 9, on 2d. May, in Lucretia-street, Lambet—I told him the charge, and asked him if his name was Bell—he said, "No"—he asked two or three times what the charge was; and I said, "Do you know a man named French?"—he said, "Your duty is to caution me that what I say will appear in evidence against me"—I said, "You are very right"—he begged to be treated as a gentleman, as he was a solicitor—when we got to Blackman-street, Borough, he said, "If I know French, I will eat a b—y lamp-post"—the inspector at the station asked him his name—he said, "Bell"—he was dressed in a reversible coat; he looks cleaner now than he did then.

GUILTY .*—
Confined Twelve Months each.
